conclusion: Objects A and B start moving in a straight line simultaneously and from the same location at rest. The relationship between their accelerations and time is shown in the diagram, where t₂ = 2t₁. The task is to determine if the two objects have the same velocity at time t₁.
The diagram shows acceleration-time graphs for two objects: Object A has constant acceleration (horizontal line), and Object B has linearly increasing acceleration (diagonal line).
Both objects start from rest at point O, and the red shaded area in the second image highlights the area under the acceleration curve from 0 to t₁.

The velocity of an object at any time can be calculated as v = v₀ + ∫a(t)dt. Since both objects start from rest (v₀ = 0), the velocity at time t₁ is equal to the area under the acceleration-time graph from t = 0 to t = t₁.
For Object A, the velocity at time t₁ is v_A(t₁) = a_A × t₁, which is the area of the rectangle from 0 to t₁ with height a_A.
For Object B, the acceleration can be expressed as a_B(t) = (a_B(t₁)/t₁) × t, and the velocity at time t₁ is v_B(t₁) = (1/2) × t₁ × a_B(t₁), which is the area of the triangle from 0 to t₁.
At time t₁, the velocity of A is a_A × t₁, and the velocity of B is (1/2) × t₁ × a_B(t₁). For these velocities to be equal, a_A × t₁ = (1/2) × t₁ × a_B(t₁), which simplifies to a_A = (1/2) × a_B(t₁).
From the diagram, at time t₁, the acceleration of B (a_B(t₁)) is exactly twice the acceleration of A (a_A). This is observed by examining the height of the acceleration curves at time t₁.
Since a_A = (1/2) × a_B(t₁), the velocities of A and B at time t₁ are equal.

The final answer is: Yes, the two objects have the same velocity at time t₁ because the area under the acceleration-time graph for object A (a rectangle) equals the area under the acceleration-time graph for object B (a triangle) from t = 0 to t = t₁.
